titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went with Seidler to the Zackenfall— Return’d at about 6 in the evening— Weather very warm— Poor Blanch— The wheel went over her, and broke her shoulder bone.
2. About 6 this morning we set out, and went to the Snow-pits and the Elbe-fall— Met young Count Unruh at the Schlingel’s baude.— Return’d in the evening at 7.— Rain’d a little upon our return.

3. Set out at 7. this morning upon our expedition to the Schneekoppe— Went to Seydorf— Stay’d there untill 4. in the afternoon— Went to Church— Ascended the mountain as far as the Hempel’s baude. Saw a fire in the plains below.

4. Slept upon hay— Rose at 2. Mrs: A— had a head ache and could not go with us. Went upon the koppe to see the sun-rise— Returning to the baude, met Mrs: A. whose head-ache had left her— Went up with her again. Return’d to the baude at about 9.— Thence went to the little lake—at 11. found our cart at the Schlingel’s baude where we left it last night— Return’d through Warmbrunn to Hirschberg where we arrived at 3. in the afternoon; well nigh roasted with heat.

5. Rose early this morning; and went over the Lutheran church, and church-yard— Afterwards walk’d to the Schlossberg, the hill opposite the Helicon— Went up to look for the ruins of the old castle, said to be upon it, but could not find them— Afternoon and evening spent in writing— Whitcomb went to Schreibershau, and brought back the things we had left there.

6. The post-master called upon us this forenoon. Took a walk round the neighbourhood of the town, after dinner. Went to the play and saw the Tyrolian, an Opera— The singing very bad. Met Madame de Castel and Count & Countess Unruh there.

7. Went with the post-master, to Mr: Reinhardt the painter’s, and saw his Silesian views— Took four of his coloured prints, comprizing the whole range of the mountains— Met there Mr: Hess, a merchant who recollected having once dined with me at Mr: Schickler’s in Berlin, and offered us all the services in his power— The rain prevented us/ from going any further this forenoon; but not from going to the play after dinner— We saw Julius von Sassen a political tragedy in four acts by the author of Abellino.— It rain’d hard when we came home.

8. We went this afternoon with Mr: Reinhardt, to Stohnsdorf, a village and chateau, belonging to count Reuss. Saw the charming view from the Stangenbusch; and the wild massive rocks of the Prudelberg. The former, Reinhardt has taken as the point of view— Had a beautiful prospect of the Sun, setting upon the mountains as we return’d home.

9. Mrs: Hess attended us this forenoon and shew’d us the sugar-refinery—and the specimens of turnip sugar, which they have made— We afterwards went to Lähnhaus, the seat of a Baron Grünfeld; two German miles, on the road to Löwenberg.— Saw the ruins of the old castle; the church of St. Hedwige, and the new chateau & gardens. The prospects are charming— Return’d to Hirschberg this evening.

10. Went to the Lutheran church this forenoon, and heard the religious services perform’d.— Mr: Hess sent us his mother’s carriage, to go and dine at the table d’hôte in the gallery at Warmbrunn— After dinner we went with him to his bleachery.— Return’d for half an hour to the gallery, where we saw Countess Haugwitz— They have balls on Sundays and Thursdays, but the arrangements are not good— Scarcely even decent— The building itself is very elegant— We return’d home at about 7 this evening.

11 We went this forenoon, and took leave of Mr: and Mrs: Schäfer, who gave us letters for Landshut and Waldenburg. At five in the afternoon, left Hirschberg and came to Schmiedeberg— Lodge at the sign of the black horse.— Went and delivered my letter to Mr: Hoffman, who told me he was obliged to go to-morrow morning to Hirschberg, to see a lady whom he is about to marry.

12. Wrote, most of the forenoon.— Between two and three o’clock Mr: Friderici came, at the desire of his friend Mr: Hoffman, and attended us to see Mr: Waldkirch’s bleachery, Mr: Gebauer’s tape manufactory, the printed linen and handkerchief manufactory of Messrs: Brincker and Schneider, and the damask manufactory and store of Mr: Weber— Likewise to Buchwald, Count Redern country seat, where we found Mr: & Mrs: Schäfer. The Count himself is gone to Waldenburg, to make arrangements for the reception of the queen at the mines.

13. Mr: Hoffman called upon us this morning; and Mr: Friderici’s brother came and attended us to Mr: Gentsch’s bleachery, and to see his glazing machine— All these principal linen merchants have the title of commerzienrath’s. I afterwards went to see the prospect from the Friesensteine; about a german mile from Schniedeberg. Between two and three, return’d to our inn; and after dinner, came to Landeshut; met Count Redern on the road— At Landeshut we lodge at the sign of the black raven on the ring— Delivered a letter this evening to Mr: Ruck.

14. Mr: Ruck called upon us this morning with his carriage, and took us to the cloister at Grüssau. We returned to dine with him and a large company at Landeshut. Spent the evening there likewise— Played whist.

15. We went this forenoon with Mr: and Mrs: Ruck, and saw the town library and the lutheran church, which is built upon the same model as that of Hirschberg—but without paintings— The library is small, and not very valuable— This afternoon we came through Gottesberg to Waldenburg, three miles. Found some difficulty to get lodgings.

16. Mr: Treutler to whom we had a letter called upon us this morning, and procured us the occasion to go down into the coal mines, by the canal under water— Delivered a letter to Mr: Töpfer— He invited us to breakfast with him to-morrow morning at Altwasser.— Took a walk this evening upon a neighbouring hill that overlooks the town. The prospect very fine.

17. Breakfasted this morning with Mr: Töpfer and his family at Altwasser— Walked after breakfast with them about the place— Introduced to Mr: Mutius, the owner of it— After dinner, went to the Lutheran church, and the catholic chapel— Then to Furstenstein, where we were introduced to Count and Countess Hochberg. The latter a princess of Pless.
18. Went this morning to Adersbach.— Mrs: A— frightened— Return’d towards Evening to Waldenburg.— Pass’d the evening and supp’d at Mr: Töpfers— Cards— Mrs: A. could not go.

19. Dined early, and went immediately afterwards to Fürstenstein; where we saw the carousel. Afterwards at the masked ball— Returned to Waldenburg about midnight— The king and queen pass’d, this morning.
20. The queen pass’d again, to go to Adersbach— This afternoon we came 3. german miles to Schweidnitz— Saw the lime pits at Freyburg.— Good house at Schweidnitz.

21. Saw the queen pass at eleven this morning— Intended to go this afternoon to Zobten, but deferred it owing to Whitcomb’s illness, and the prospect of bad weather— Saw the catholic church this afternoon, and went up the steeple— Fine view— Likewise the lutheran church, & church-yard.

22. Left Schweidnitz, between 6 and 7 this morning. Went through Reichenbach, Frankenstein, and Wartha—arrived at Glatz at about 7 in the evening. Distance 7. german miles— Roads very good. Queen return’d this evening from Landeck.

23. Sent to the commandant, general Rabiel to enquire, whether we could see the fortress— He made some scruple owing to Governor Favrat’s absence.— We left Whitcomb, who has the fever, at Glatz; and went on to Landeck— Walk to see the baths, springs and glass-shops.

24. Walk’d this morning to see the temple built by Count Hoym, and the walks laid out in the woods. At eleven, left Landeck, with a guide, and went to see the water fall at Wölfelsgründe— Roads very bad— Returning, we pass’d through the ruins of the town of Habelschwerd, which was burnt down, five days ago— Not a private house in the town left— At eleven in the evening we came to the gates of Glatz— They had been shut at ten— We took our lodging at an inn without the town.
25. Came into Glatz this morning— Mrs: A. excessively fatigued— In the afternoon, I took a chaise alone and went three miles to Wünschelburg; to go up the Heuscheuer.

26. Rose at 2 this morning; enclosed a letter for my brother to be forwarded from Glatz. At three sat out, with my guide and went up the Heuscheuer— Two hours and a half, quick walking. Reached the summit just after sun rise— Wind very high and cold— Return’d to Wünschelburg between 8 and 9. Visit from the burgomaster— On my way back to Glatz saw the church with the miraculous image at Almendorf, and Count Magné’s seat and sheepcote at Eckersdorf.— Reach’d Glatz between 3. and 4. this afternoon— Delivered a letter from the Minister Alvensleben to lieutt: General de Favrat Governor of Glatz, who return’d yesterday from the review at Neyss.

27. The governor sent us his carriage to go out and see the entry of the two regiments and one battalion, from the review at Neyss. Afterwards went with us up the fortress— We dined with him and a company of about twenty persons— At 5 in the afternoon left Glatz and came to Frankenstein.

28. Went this morning in a post-chaise to Silberberg, and saw the fortress there— The commandant had received notice from general Favrat of our coming, and was very obliging— He detained us to dinner, after which we return’d to Frankenstein, and thence proceeded four miles through Nimptsch to Jordansmühle, where we found the worst inn we have yet met with on this road. I was obliged to sleep upon straw.

29. At two this morning, I took a postilion with me, and went on horse-back to the little town of Zobten; there I found a guide who went with me up the mountain of the same name— The morning was cloudy and the atmosphere thick so that I could not fully enjoy the prospect— On my return, breakfasted at Zobten; and got to Jordansmühle at ten— Went on five miles through Dombslau to Breslau, where we arrived between 3 and 4 in the afternoon.— We lodge at the Ville de Paris; though after arriving here we were informed the best inn is at the three mountains.

30. Dull and rainy weather— Writing all the forenoon— Took a walk in the afternoon— Went to Korn’s large and well furnish’d book-store for a description of the town and a plan. Took Delille’s french georgics, and read the first book in the evening.

31. Continues rainy; went to the church of St: Christopher where I heard part of a sermon in the polish language. To that of St: Elisabeth—that of Mary Magdalen, and the catholic, cathedral church of upon the Dome island. In the evening went to the play, and saw the beggar student, and the Comedy extempore, both very indifferent pieces. The players are barely tolerable.
Day— As the last month.
